entry.et: Middle English whete, from Old English hwǣte; akin to Old High German weizzi wheat, hwīz, wīz white white

def.dt: :a cereal grain that yields a fine white flour used chiefly in breads, baked goods (as cakes and crackers), and pastas (as macaroni or spaghetti), and is important in animal feeds
:any of various Old World annual grasses (genus Triticum, especially T. aestivum and T. turgidum) of wide climatic adaptability that are cultivated in most temperate areas for the wheat they yield
:a bread made of a combination of white and whole wheat flours as distinguished from bread made entirely of white or whole wheat flour
:the embryo of the wheat kernel separated in milling and used especially as a source of vitamins and protein
:a destructive disease of wheat caused by rust fungi
:a fungus (as Puccinia graminis) causing a wheat rust
city N cen Colorado W of Denver pop 32,913

entry.et: New Latin durum, from Latin, neuter of durus hard

def.dt: :a wheat (Triticum durum) that yields a glutenous flour used especially in pasta called also durum
:a wheat with hard kernels that are high in gluten and that yield a flour especially suitable for bread and macaroni
